# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
import seaborn as sns


# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))
        
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session
source.95257821:
plt.figure(figsize=(16,10))
sns.barplot(x=data["Sex"], y= data["Survived"], hue = data["Pclass"])
source.6b979b35:
plt.figure(figsize=(16,7))
sns.kdeplot(data = data['Age'], shade = True)
plt.axvline(x = data['Age'].mean(), color = 'red', label = "Mean")
plt.axvline(x = data['Age'].median(), color = 'green', label = "Median" )
plt.legend(loc = 'upper left')
source.3dfd2365:
gdata = data.groupby(data.Sex)
maledata = gdata.get_group("male")
femaledata = gdata.get_group("female")
source.b49b00b4:
plt.figure(figsize = (16,8))
sns.distplot(a = maledata["Age"],label = "Male")
sns.distplot(a = femaledata["Age"], label = "Female")
plt.legend(loc = 'upper left')
plt.axvline(x = maledata['Age'].mean(), color = 'red',label = "Male mean value")
plt.axvline(x = femaledata['Age'].mean(), color = 'green',label = "Female mean value")
plt.legend(loc = 'upper left')
source.17d92bcc:
gdata = data.groupby(data.Survived)
SurData = gdata.get_group(1)
PerData = gdata.get_group(0)
source.7c84d991:
plt.figure(figsize = (16,8))
sns.distplot(SurData["Age"], label = "Survived")
sns.distplot(PerData["Age"], label = "Perished")
plt.legend(loc = 'upper left')
source.243006e2:
plt.figure(figsize = (16,8))
sns.countplot(x = SurData["SibSp"])
plt.ylabel("No of passengers")
plt.title("Survived")
source.9c75e0d2:

plt.ylabel("No of passengers")
plt.title("Perished")

source.7938839e:
plt.figure(figsize = (16,8))
sns.swarmplot(x = data["Pclass"], y = data["Fare"], hue = data["Survived"])
L = plt.legend()
L.get_texts()[0].set_text("Perished")
L.get_texts()[1].set_text("Survived")
source.0d9b0a54:
What the graphs tell us:
* Passengers with a larger number of sibling or spouses (3<) were more likely to perish
source.8d21e832:
What the graph tells us:

* Very young children had a very high survival rate 
* Greatest amount of people to perish were between the ages of 20 and 30 (this is also the most common ages of all passengers are in this range so this may not be statistically significant
* Everybody between the age of 65 and 75 perished 
* Everybody between the age of 75 and 80 survived

source.ac2b0dbf:
**Hi there**,

**This is just a small note book of me plotting and interperating some graphs**
source.48acb423:
What the graph tells us:
* The most likely to survive are women in First class
* The least likely to survive are men in Third class
* Women have a much greater chance of surviving over men.
source.a90b2bf1:
What the graphs tells us:
* Fare goes against the trend between class and survival and shows no real trend at all relative to survival
* There is very little difference between the fare of second and third class and a larger proportion of first class
